articles.title: Trump says he’s seriously considering taking Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac public
articles.description: Mortgage finance firms Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were placed in conservatorship after housing collapse in 2008
articles.content:
U.S. President Donald Trump said on Wednesday he will make a decision in the near future about taking mortgage finance firms Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac public, saying that he is giving “very serious consideration” to doing so.

articles.description: The new U.S. ambassador to Canada says while U.S. President Donald Trump is unlikely to ever remove his slate of tariffs entirely, he’s confident Canada can reach a deal to secure the lowest levies possible.
articles.content:
U.S. Ambassador to Canada Pete Hoekstra says Canada and the U.S. 'would have to have some kind of a discussion on NORAD' if Canada doesn't buy F35s.

articles.title: House Republicans pass Trump’s big bill of tax breaks after all-night session
articles.description: The outcome caps an intense time on Capitol Hill, with days of private negotiations and public committee hearings around-the-clock.
articles.content:
House Republicans stayed up all night to pass their multitrillion-dollar tax breaks package, with speaker Mike Johnson defying the sceptics and unifying his ranks to muscle US President Donald Trump’s priority bill to approval.

articles.title: US Mint moves forward with plans to kill the penny
articles.description: Donald Trump has described the penny as ‘wasteful’.
articles.content:
The US Mint has made its final order of penny blanks and plans to stop producing the coin when those run out, a Treasury Department official confirmed on Thursday.

articles.title: Trump administration bars Harvard from enrolling foreign students
articles.description: The Department of Homeland Security has claimed Harvard has created an unsafe campus environment.
articles.content:
The Trump administration has revoked Harvard University’s ability to enrol international students in its escalating battle with the Ivy League school, saying thousands of current students must transfer to other schools or leave the country.
